pageProps.body:
The 7 Most Influential Papers in Computer Science History

https://terriblesoftware.org/2025/01/22/the-7-most-influential-papers-in-computer-science-history/

Before we begin, let me be clear: yes, this is a subjective list. It‚Äôs not meant to end the debate ‚Äî but to start it. These seven papers (sorted by date) stand out to me mostly because of their impact in today‚Äôs world. Honestly, each one deserves a blog post (or even a book!) of its own ‚Äî but let‚Äôs keep it short for now. If your favorite doesn‚Äôt show up here, don‚Äôt worry, stick around for the bonus section at the end, where I‚Äôll call out a few more that came this close to making the main list. So let‚Äôs dive in!

1. ‚ÄúOn Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem‚Äù (1936)

Author: Alan Turing

It‚Äôs the 1930s, and a ‚Äúprogrammable machine‚Äù sounds like something out of a sci-fi novel. Then along comes Alan Turing, laying the groundwork for what computers can theoretically do. He sketches out a hypothetical ‚ÄúTuring Machine,‚Äù proving that, if something is computable at all, a machine (in principle) can handle it.

The big idea

Turing‚Äôs simple model ‚Äî just a tape, a head for reading/writing, and a finite set of states, turned into the granddaddy of all modern computation. It defined what‚Äôs solvable (and what‚Äôs not) in a purely mechanical sense, basically giving us the ‚Äúrules of the game‚Äù for digital problem-solving.

Why it matters today

Every single programming language, every single piece of code out there, is playing by Turing‚Äôs rules. Even when we talk about quantum computing, we‚Äôre still referencing the boundaries Turing described. That‚Äôs a huge testament to the power of one paper published in the mid-1930s.

Learn more

  • https://www.cs.virginia.edu/~robins/Turing_Paper_1936.pdf
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing%27s_proof
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNRDvLACg5Q

2. ‚ÄúA Mathematical Theory of Communication‚Äù (1948)

Author: Claude Shannon

Now that Turing showed us what machines can (and can‚Äôt) do, how do we actually move information around? Enter Claude Shannon, who basically invented information theory so we could talk about bits, entropy, and noisy channels in a rigorous way.

The big idea

Shannon took the abstract notion of ‚Äúinformation‚Äù and turned it into something a little bit (pun intended) more measurable. This helped us figure out how to pack data more efficiently (compression) and how to protect it from errors (error-correcting codes), whether we‚Äôre sending signals into space or streaming Netflix on a Friday night.

Why it matters today

Every single time you send a text, stream a video, or call your mom on FaceTime, you‚Äôre using Shannon‚Äôs ideas. Without them, you‚Äôd be dealing with a lot more scrambled audio and jumbled data, trust me.

Learn more

  • https://people.math.harvard.edu/~ctm/home/text/others/shannon/entropy/entropy.pdf
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Mathematical_Theory_of_Communication
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b6VdGHSV6qg
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kP0zi5lX-Fo

3. ‚ÄúA Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks‚Äù (1970)

Author: Edgar F. Codd

So, we can compute and communicate ‚Äî awesome. But eventually, we‚Äôre buried under mountains of data. Edgar F. Codd saw this coming and introduced the relational model, which is basically the reason we‚Äôre able to store and query data.

The big idea

Codd said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs store data in tables and manipulate it with logical operations.‚Äù This might sound obvious now, but at the time it was revolutionary. His blueprint led to SQL and the huge family of relational databases that power, oh, basically every bank, retail website, and enterprise system you can imagine.

Why it matters today

Even in the NoSQL era, the underlying concepts of how we organize data (tables, schemas, consistency) trace right back to Codd. If you ever wrote a SQL query in your life ‚Äî it‚Äôs all thanks to him.

Learn more

  • https://www.seas.upenn.edu/~zives/03f/cis550/codd.pdf
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Codd%27s_12_rules

4. ‚ÄúThe Complexity of Theorem-Proving Procedures‚Äù (1971)

Author: Stephen A. Cook

Now that we‚Äôre storing data efficiently, what about the computation itself? Turns out some problems are just‚Ä¶painfully hard. Stephen Cook‚Äôs paper introduced NP-completeness, a concept that basically says, ‚ÄúYep, some tasks are so difficult that even supercomputers sweat.‚Äù

The big idea

Cook showed that the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT) is NP-complete, meaning if you magically solve SAT quickly, you‚Äôve instantly cracked a whole bunch of other seemingly impossible problems. This created a universal language for talking about problem difficulty.

Why it matters today

Whenever you see ‚ÄúNP-hard‚Äù in a problem description, or wonder why route optimization kills your CPU, that‚Äôs Cook‚Äôs legacy. It led to huge developments in algorithms, cryptography, and the hunt for efficient solutions (or at least decent approximations).

Learn more

  • https://www.inf.unibz.it/~calvanese/teaching/14-15-tc/material/cook-1971-NP-completeness-of-SAT.pdf
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_versus_NP_problem
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dJUEkjxylBw

5. ‚ÄúA Protocol for Packet Network Intercommunication‚Äù (1974)

Authors: Vinton G. Cerf and Robert E. Kahn

Great, we have tough problems to solve and data to store ‚Äî but how do we hook all these computers together? Cerf and Kahn‚Äôs TCP turned isolated networks into an interconnected web, letting data hop around the planet in tiny packets.

The big idea

They created a universal language for different networks to talk. Packets get split up, zipped through various routes, and reassembled on the other side. This flexibility opened the door for global connectivity ‚Äî no single monolithic network required.

Why it matters today

Short answer? Pretty much the entire internet. Whenever you browse the web, send an email, or securely log in to your bank‚Äôs website, you‚Äôre leaning on TCP/IP to move those bits around reliably. Sure, some real-time applications might use UDP, but the core idea of IP-based networking ‚Äî laid out by Cerf and Kahn ‚Äî still unites all our devices under one global network.

Learn more

  • https://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/fall06/cos561/papers/cerf74.pdf
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PG9oKZdFb7w

6. ‚ÄúInformation Management: A Proposal‚Äù (1989)

Author: Tim Berners-Lee

And speaking of TCP/IP ‚Äî once machines could talk to each other easily, Tim Berners-Lee asked, ‚ÄúHow about we make this thing friendly for everyone?‚Äù That‚Äôs where the World Wide Web was born.

The big idea

Berners-Lee pitched a global hypertext system, complete with hyperlinks, URLs, and HTTP. Suddenly, documents around the world were no longer isolated; they were ‚Äúwebbed‚Äù together, turning the internet into something normal people (not just scientists) could navigate.

Why it matters today

We live on the web. Whether it‚Äôs social media, online shopping, or reading obscure blog posts at 3 a.m., the seeds of it all came from this straightforward proposal. It changed how we share knowledge forever.

Learn more

  • https://cds.cern.ch/record/369245/files/dd-89-001.pdf
  • https://time.com/21039/tim-berners-lee-web-proposal-at-25/
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qJNrvVv7SdU

7. ‚ÄúThe Anatomy of a Large-Scale Hypertextual Web Search Engine‚Äù (1998)

Authors: Sergey Brin and Larry Page

Once Berners-Lee‚Äôs web blew up, it became a jungle of links, pages, and cat memes. Sergey Brin and Larry Page decided to tame that jungle. Their approach, based on link analysis, evolved into the search engine we now call ‚ÄúGoogle.‚Äù

The big idea

They introduced PageRank, which viewed links as votes of confidence rather than just a new dimension to count keywords. The result was a seismic jump in relevant search results, making the web feel, well‚Ä¶searchable.

Why it matters today

Type a question into Google and get an instant answer? That‚Äôs PageRank (and a lot of subsequent innovation) at work. It redefined how we navigate information online and kicked off a new era of data-driven tech‚Äîads, analytics, machine learning, you name it.

Learn more

  • https://snap.stanford.edu/class/cs224w-readings/Brin98Anatomy.pdf
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PageRank
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v7n7wZhHJj8&t=184s

Bonuses (5 That Almost Made the List)

1. ‚ÄúRecursive Functions of Symbolic Expressions and Their Computation by Machine‚Äù (1960) ‚Äì John McCarthy

Introduced Lisp and the functional programming style that still sneaks into modern languages and frameworks.

2. ‚ÄúGo To Statement Considered Harmful‚Äù (1968) ‚Äì Edsger Dijkstra

A short but fiery editorial that argued goto leads to messy, unstructured code, sparking the structured programming revolution.

3. ‚ÄúTime, Clocks, and the Ordering of Events in a Distributed System‚Äù (1978) ‚Äì Leslie Lamport

You can‚Äôt sync real clocks perfectly in distributed systems, so you need logical ones. This is a must-read if you‚Äôre into distributed computing.

4. ‚ÄúNo Silver Bullet‚ÄîEssence and Accident in Software Engineering‚Äù (1986) ‚Äì Fred Brooks

Brooks argued that there‚Äôs no single magical fix for the inherent complexity of software development. Decades later, as we chase the ‚Äúnext big thing‚Äù in frameworks or methodologies, his message remains a sobering reminder that some problems are just hard.

5. ‚ÄúAttention Is All You Need‚Äù (2017) ‚Äì Vaswani et al.

The transformer architecture behind GPT and other big-name AI models. If you‚Äôre impressed by large language models, here‚Äôs your blueprint.

Conclusion

These days, we‚Äôre flooded with new stuff: fresh languages, mind-blowing AI breakthroughs, quantum leaps, and the JavaScript framework of the week. It‚Äôs all super exciting, but here‚Äôs the thing: foundations matter. Without them, we‚Äôre just piling on new toys without fully understanding the ground we‚Äôre building on. The papers in this post are a reminder of where our core concepts ‚Äî data structures, algorithms, the very web ‚Äî came from.
